2. Key concepts and arguments that intersect literary and feminist studies

4. Ability to synthesize disparate materials and formulate cogent questions"

outline.ch: "This class explores narratives of present and future women’s emancipation and liberation entangled with narratives of familial and national, capitalist, socialist and/or communist, past and present injustice and exploitation. We will learn about third world feminisms (Jayawardena) and world literature (Jameson and Prasad), Marxist feminist theorization of world historical “housewifization” (Mies) and the “ungendering” that is Atlantic slavery as institution (Spillers) alongside a series of US “sex wars” essays. Putting this material together will help us in reading and asking questions of feminist fictional and theoretical narratives. We will read fictions that theorize and theories that tell a story about women’s problems and empowerment, with varying emphases, turning points and catalysts, toward transformation of conditions that structurally enable multiple inequalities. Your task will be to read with care, continuously engaging with each text as you describe, summarize, and analyze, toward a working paper that synthesizes select materials from the course in a final paper."
